Award.AwardTitle: Rapid: Assessing Temporal Dynamics of Disturbance Interactions as a Driver of a Novel Forest Mortality Event
Award.AbstractNarration:
In many forested regions of the world, disturbances caused by introduced pests and pathogens, along with changing climatic conditions, has resulted in forest health impacts. As these types of disturbances become more frequent, the interactions between them can greatly amplify the impacts on forest health and sustainability. This project will study an unprecedented, ongoing forest mortality event that affects oak-dominated forests in southern New England. Tree mortaility appears to be related to the interaction of both drought and multiple canopy defoliations by non-native Gypsy Moth caterpillars. This project will evaluate how the timing and interactions of those disturbances matters in forest health. The research will assess if areas that have greater tree mortality are those that experienced the most intense initial drought or if they underwent defoliation closer in time to the drought. The results of the project will be very valuable to forest stakeholders, helping them understand the underlying causes of the tree mortality event and potentially allowing prediction of future impacts. The investigators are highly engaged with the regional forest management community and the results of the project will be used in planning forest management strategies including tree removals related to this mortality event. The project is important as it will communicate the potential ramifications for wood products markets, forestry and arboriculture practices, and general forest use by the public.

Interactions between climate-mediated disturbances, such as droughts, and biotic disturbances, such as defoliating insect pests, are increasingly driving continental-scale forest structure and function. However, the temporal lags associated with drought effects on biotic disturbance are not well understood and empirical data to address this topic are lacking. The central hypothesis of this project is that the effect of interacting drought and defoliation disturbance will be mediated by temporal proximity between disturbances and initial drought severity. The project will combine high temporal and spatial resolution remote sensing analysis with dendrochronological reconstruction of forest growth patterns to assess how the timing and severity of interacting disturbances affects patterns of disturbance resistance, forest productivity, and tree mortality in temperate forest ecosystems. The study will be conducted in a network of forest stands, identified through the remote sensing analysis, which will be replicated across categories of defoliation timing in relation to the initial drought disturbance. The results of the project will support hypothesis generation, model parameterization, and general conceptual frameworks for future experimental and modeling studies that can evaluate the mechanistic basis for, and consequences of, disturbance interactions in terrestrial ecosystems.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Following the completion of our <1 year project, early findings support hypotheses articulated in our RAPID proposal and have produced intriguing results that are motivating ongoing and collaborative research. Initial results support the general idea that tree mortality outcomes are highly dependent on disturbance timing and frequency as well as severity. Further analysis of increment core tree growth data will build upon these initial results by providing new information on the relationship between timing of growth reductions and mortality related to defoliation patterns that are detectable using remote sensing platforms. Our findings will advance the fundamental understanding and modeling of the effects of interacting disturbances on growth and mortality outcomes in forest ecosystems. Specifically we have produced a substantial and novel dataset on the importance of disturbance timing as a component of disturbance interactions from both the individual tree and forest stand perspective, which can be used to parameterize models focused on projecting the effects of such disturbances. This dataset will be made publically available following completion of data processing and quality control to promote the utility of the work to the broader ecological community. The RAPID award has facilitated the development of a multi-institution regional collaborative network focused on understanding and responding to the forest mortality event related to the combination of gypsy moth defoliation and drought. PI Fahey and collaborators have also participated in a regional Forest Pest Risk Working Group that includes gypsy moth as one of it focal pests. Early results produced from this award will be the topic of an invited presentation at a special session on tree mortality at the Ecological Society of America Annual Meeting in August 2020. UConn MS student Danielle Tanzer will be the lead presenter and PI Fahey the senior co-author. Several publications are expected to be produced from this award by the project team and collaborators following the end date of this short preliminary project. This will include 2-3 publications associated with the MS Thesis of Danielle Tanzer and the undergraduate Honors Thesis of UConn University Scholar Mari Cullerton, both of whom are utilizing the data generated in this project in their ongoing work. Broader impacts of the project include substantial benefits for and interactions with the forest management and utility/infrastructure sectors in the Northeast region and beyond. Products of the work will be valuable in addressing the scope of the current widespread mortality event and preparing for and responding to future events. The results of this project will be utilized to develop a more resilient forest and, by extension, a more resilient coupled human-natural system surrounding forests and related infrastructure.
